pullRequest.body: We provide a simple non-linear recurrence relation for the Fermat numbers. Since this involves subtraction, both Nat and Int versions are given.

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5c75ec4b6a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17659/commits/5c75ec4b6a7905618dc8a8aa97d93ad1f8a0b759)

| %      | File |
| -      | -    |
| +5.90% | `Mathlib.NumberTheory.Fermat` |

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.NumberTheory.Fermat | 678 | 718 | +40 (+5.90%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.Fermat`|40|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Int.fermatNumber_eq_fermatNumber_sq_sub_two_mul_fermatNumber_sub_one_sq`
`+ fermatNumber_eq_fermatNumber_sq_sub_two_mul_fermatNumber_sub_one_sq`
`+ two_mul_fermatNumber_sub_one_sq_le_fermatNumber_sq`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
Can I ask what this lemma is needed for? It's a bit specific and the use of natural subtraction makes me a bit iffy.

> Can I ask what this lemma is needed for? It's a bit specific and the use of natural subtraction makes me a bit iffy.

I needed this when I was showing that for all `n > 1`, the Fermat Number `F_n` can be written in infinitely many ways as `n^2 - 2m^2` for positive natural `m` and `n`. For this one needs a starting case and then can construct bigger and bigger examples. (Now of course one can ask what this would be needed for...)
I though this two term non-linear recursion is so basic that it might be useful in other contexts. 
But I'm happy to close this pr if you think it is useless.
I think I partly share the suspicion of natural subtraction, at least I can't think of other simple recursive formulas relating simple sequences of natural numbers, which cannot be rewritten in a way to avoid the subtraction.

It's a general fact that given any nonzero integer `t`, if the solution `x ^ 2 - 2 * y ^ 2 = t` has one solution, it has infinitely many (and similarly for `x ^ 2 - d y^2` for any positive squarefree `d`). This follows from the theory of Pell equations. So the "infinitely many ways" assertion is not surprising here. 

I think there's no harm in adding a lemma for the specific identity you're using here, `fermatNumber (n + 2) = (fermatNumber (n + 1)) ^ 2 - 2 * (fermatNumber n - 1) ^ 2`. But it needs a better name; and  I completely agree with @vihdzp that the use of Nat subtraction should be avoided. I would suggest you write it as an identity for `(fermatNumber (n + 2) : \Z)` instead, so the subtraction on the RHS is interpreted as integer rather than Nat subtraction.

I think that writing this for the integers is also the sort of thing that can result in a theorem statement that ends up not being very useful. I would like there to be an actual purpose to proving this.

Meh, we're doing pure mathematics here, what does "actual purpose" mean? :smile: 

Seriously, there is some genuine mathematical interest in determining for which `n` the statement `∃ (x y : ℤ), x ^ 2 - 2 * y ^ 2 = n` is true (while there is definitely no interest at all in the analogue for Nat subtraction). The identity used here is perhaps not deep, but it is kind of cute. I would vote for merging, and we can let Moritz show us in later PR's what he wants this identity for.

I'm still keen that we should have a version of the statement using Int rather than Nat subtraction. Could you add this as well? It should be very quick to do given that you have the inequality already.
bors d=loefflerd

:v: loefflerd can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

> I'm still keen that we should have a version of the statement using Int rather than Nat subtraction. Could you add this as well? It should be very quick to do given that you have the inequality already.

I added a `Int` version. Not sure if this is what you had in mind: distinguishing them by namespace.

This is pretty much ready now; once CI passes, I'll hit merge. Can you add a sentence or two of description to the github PR page header? This will be automatically picked up by the merge script and used as the commit message.
Done, thanks for the review, @loefflerd
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11398034462/job/31714426466)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11398034462/job/31714426232)

Please restore the blank line separating this declaration from the previous. Also, as I already suggested, this theorem needs a different name; it's not as if anyone who encounters "fermatNumber (n + 2)" in their goal state will automatically be wanting to use this theorem, it's more specialised than that. I think it should have a name based on the RHS of the statement as well. Perhaps "fermatNumber_eq_fermatNumber_sq_sub_two_mul_fermatNumber_sub_one_sq".

I renamed as suggested.
Also I was thinking a bit about if we rather want the int version of this, but I am not really certain. Perhaps it would be a good idea having the inequality that shows that the Nat subtraction will always yield the same result as the Int subtraction (after casting)?
See added lemma
I’d prefer reformulating to use Int subtraction. Nat subtraction is a fundamentally un-mathematical operation.

```suggestion
  simp only [fermatNumber, push_cast, add_tsub_cancel_right]
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/FermatNumber): fermatNumber n + 2
